transcript.page:
fol.200r
S
r
. Yo
r
last letters comen to my hands are of the xxvj
th
of the last
moneth, whearew
th
yowe sent a letter unto hir
Ma
tie
for awnsweare to
a matter longe a goe proposed concerning the Comerce and Trade w
th
the
Ennemie: but howe theie have awnsweared it I knowe not, bicawse I
have not delivered the letter at the present writing: but if theie shall
continue soe free a kinde of trafficque as theie doe theie shall make
[warre] with one hand and peace w
th
the other, wheareas hir Ma
tie
is
forced, followinge the forme of the Contract, by makinge warre w
th
both
hir handes: but hereof I can write noe more untill hir Ma
tie
have perused
the letter./
As to the other matter for the execuc
o
n of soe vigorous a placart against
o
r
marchantes
Cloathes theare, in w
ch
matter theie have written at great
length, thowgh contentiouslie, whearew
th
hir Ma
tie
is noe waies satisfied
as I think by sum letter from hir Ma
tie
will shortlie appeare, & thowgh
theie have yelded to have the matter to be refered to Committees, yet it
weare reason in the meane season that execuc
o
n of the placart might
cease, untill the Commissioners appointed on both partes maie make
sum good ende thearein: and soe the marchant
shall thinke themselves
beholdinge unto yowe, if yowe shall procure such a [surceance:] and assone
as I can have anie leisure w
th
hir Ma
tie
, I will procure hir Ma
ties
l
re
s
to the same effect./
I perceive that hir Ma
ties
l
re
s of the xvij
th
came not to yo
r
handes
untill the xxvj
th
, w
ch
I thinke hath hapned by the Contrarietye of
windes, [be sorie] thereof considering of what importance the request of
hir Ma
tie
to the
States
and
Comte Maurice
was for the aide of the
Frenche
K.
and thowgh as yowe write that theie weare written at the time
that the K. was in distresse, and that nowe at the time of yo
r
writinge
yowe are advertised of the Ennemies distresse, whearebie yowe woulde
have mee conjecture that theie will delaie theire awnsweare, yet such
is the [state] both of the Frenche K. and the Ennemie at this present
that thowgh the Ennemie indeade be driven to sum streight
, yet the
oportunitie of the aide at this present time is such as woulde make a
full ende of the Cawse to the good of the K. and the ruin of the Ennemy.
And therefore there was never greate occasion to prosper the K. estate
than is even nowe to have him further succoured, whoe thought he be
Superio
r
to his Ennemie in horsemen, yet not equall in footemen, wherby
the Ennemie takinge adv a ntages of grownde and plac
is likely to
pressure himself sum time from the Battell, w
ch
the Frenche K. is
fol.200v
readie everie daie to offer him, and therebie shall be forced
[to]
deminishe his Armie: the onelie polecie of the Ennemie to re
[.]
self at this time./
And thus occasioned for or Merchant
Cow
[.]
write w
th
speed I make an ende of further writing. From
[.]
this v
th
of Maye.
1592.
Yo
r
vearie Lovinge frend./ William Burghley
